subject: RE: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Why exactly do the return values need to be different? They need to be different if you need to know which path the code took and if there s no other way
messageBody:
> From: Vladimir Bossicard [mailto:vladimir@...]
> ...
> >
> > if(some condition is true) {
> > do some work;
> > return result1;
> > }
> > else {
> > do some other work;
> > return result2;
> > }
> >
> > ...
> ....
> If no variable is updated and it's only the computation of the return
> value that is executed, you have to choose the input of your tests so
> that these return values are different.

Why exactly do the return values need to be different?

They need to be different if you need to know which path the code took
and if there's no other way to know. However, do you really need to know
which path the code took?

Isn't it sufficient to test that you get the correct return value for
whatever combinations of input values you choose to test with?

Daniel
